ul.li1: 271 Do not boast about tomorrow,Literally “on the day of tomorrow”
ul.li2: for you do not know what the day will bring.
ul.li1: 2May another praise you and not your own mouth,
ul.li2: a stranger and not your own lips.
ul.li1: 3Heavy is a stone and weighty is sand,
ul.li2: but the provocation of a fool is heavier than both of them.
ul.li1: 4Cruel is wrath and overwhelming is anger,
ul.li2: but who will stand before jealousy?
ul.li1: 5Better a rebuke that is open
ul.li2: than a love that is hidden.
ul.li1: 6The wounds of a friend mean well,
ul.li2: but the kisses of an enemy are profane.
ul.li1: 7An appetiteLiterally “soul” that is sated spurns honey,
ul.li2: but to an appetiteLiterally “soul” that is ravenous, all bitterness is sweet.
ul.li1: 8Like a bird that strays from its nest,
ul.li2: so is a man who strays from his place.
ul.li1: 9Perfume and incense will gladden a heart,
ul.li2: and the pleasantness of one’s friend is personal advice.Literally “because of advice of a person”
ul.li1: 10As for your friend and a friend of your father, do not forsake them,
ul.li2: and the house of your brother, do not enter on the day of your calamity.
Better is a close neighbor than a distant brother.
ul.li1: 11Be wise, my child, and make my heart glad,
ul.li2: and I will answer him who reproaches me with a word.
ul.li1: 12When the clever sees danger, he hides;
ul.li2: the simple go on and suffer.
ul.li1: 13Take his garment, for he gives surety to a stranger,
ul.li2: and to an adulteressLiterally “a foreign woman”—so take his pledge.
ul.li1: 14He who blesses his neighbor with a loud voice
ul.li2: early in the morning,
a curse will be reckoned to him.
ul.li1: 15Dripping constantly on a day of heavy rain
ul.li2: and a womanOr “wife” of contention are alike.
ul.li1: 16In restraining her, he restrains wind,Or “breath, or “spirit”
ul.li2: and his right hand will grasp oilOr “fat”.
ul.li1: 17As iron sharpensOr “is united with” iron,
ul.li2: so one man sharpens another.Literally “a man sharpens the faces of his friend”
ul.li1: 18He who tends a fig tree will eat its fruit,
ul.li2: and he who guards his masterOr “lord” will be honored.
ul.li1: 19As the waters reflect face to face,Literally “the faces to the faces”
ul.li2: so the heart of a person reflects the person.
ul.li1: 20SheolA term for the place where the dead reside, i.e., the Underworld and AbaddonPoetic synonym for “Sheol.” Only mentioned in the ot in relation to Sheol, the grave, or death. will not be satisfied,
ul.li2: and the eyes of a person will not be satisfied either.
ul.li1: 21A crucible is for the silver, and a furnace for the gold,
ul.li2: but a man is tested by the mouth of him who praises him.
ul.li1: 22If you crush a fool in the mortar with the pestle along withOr “in the midst of” the crushed grain,
ul.li2: it will not drive folly from upon him.
ul.li1: 23You will surely know the conditionLiterally “faces” of your flock;
ul.li2: your heartOr “mind” attends to the herds.
ul.li1: 24For riches are not forever,
ul.li2: nor a crown for generation after generation.
ul.li1: 25When the grass is gone, then green growth will appear,
ul.li2: and the herbs of the mountains will be gathered.
ul.li1: 26Lambs will be your clothing,
ul.li2: and goats the price of the field.
ul.li1: 27And there will be enough goats’ milk for your food,
ul.li2: for the food of your household and the nourishmentLiterally “life” of your maidservants.
